feed.title: Jewishbookfinds.com
feed.subtitle: A place to share my books and interest in modern Jewish history.

entry.title: Chumash with German translation - 1866
entry.content:
This Chumash Bamidbar contains just chumash and rashi along with a German translation for each. It was printed in Pest, 1866. While in general not of any particular interest, what stands out is the way  Targum Unkelus is replaced for a German translation which they referred to as Targum Ashkenazy.

The translation was done by Yehuda/Julius Halevi Dessauer  who apparently translated a few other books as well.

Side note: Moses Mendelssohn's family name was originally Dessaur until he had it changed to Mendelssohn. I guess both families originated from Dessau.
entry.summary: This Chumash Bamidbar contains just chumash and rashi along with a German translation for each. It was printed in Pest, 1866. While in general not of any particular interest, what stands out is the way Targum Unkelus is replaced for a German translation which they referred to as Targum Ashkenazy. The translation was done by Yehuda/Julius Halevi Dessauer who apparently translated a few other books as well. Side note: Moses Mendelssohn's family name was originally Dessaur until he had it changed to Mendelssohn. I guess both families originated from Dessau.

entry.title: הנותן תשועה למלכים… Tefillah for the Government

link.title: הנותן תשועה למלכים… Tefillah for the Government

entry.content: Many old siddurim have a tefillah (prayer) for the Government/President/Emperor etc at the beginning of Shabbos or Yom Tove Mussaf davening. It was common for the siddurim to incorporate the name/s of the then present rulers directly into this tefillah. It is always interesting to see the names and families that were included. Many times these rulers were not particularly favorable to the Jews, nevertheless they were included. Seeing those names in print adds a sense of realism and history to these 100 year old siddurim. I’m sure there are siddurim from far more interesting locations with unique or unexpected monarchies in them; but for now this is what I have. Wish I had the time to look up where and when this minhag originated, would be interesting to know.
entry.summary: Many old siddurim have a tefillah (prayer) for the Government/President/Emperor etc at the beginning of Shabbos or Yom Tove Mussaf davening. It was common for the siddurim to incorporate the name/s of the then present rulers directly into this tefillah. It is always interesting to see the names and families that were included. Many times these rulers were not particularly favorable to the Jews, nevertheless they were included. Seeing those names in print adds a sense of realism and history to these 100 year old siddurim. I’m sure there are siddurim from far more interesting locations with unique or unexpected monarchies in them; but for now this is what I have. Wish I had the time to look up where and when this minhag originated, would be interesting to know.

entry.title: Danish Siddur and Seder Haftorah Early 20th century

link.title: Danish Siddur and Seder Haftorah Early 20th century

entry.content:
I recently picked up these two sefarim with Danish translation. First is Siddur Tefilas Yisroel, printed in Copenhagen 1917. Fairly straight forward, but always interesting to see Sefarim from less typical European areas. While quickly flipping through it I noticed that at the end of bentching there's a note to say "Yiru es Hashem" silently. Not a big deal, just something that stood out, as it's not mentioned in today's standard bentchers.

Next is a Seder Haftoros also printed in Copenhagen but from 1894. It has each week's haftorah along with the Danish translation. The first few pages are a list of names with the header "Subskribentfortegnelse" which seems to mean a writers list of some sort (google translate was no help; spelling must be off or maybe it needs to be broken down to multiple words?). Both translations seem to have been originally done by Rabbi Abraham Alexander Wolf. You can see in the hebrew introduction to the siddur that his fathers name was Alexander.
entry.summary: I recently picked up these two sefarim with Danish translation. First is Siddur Tefilas Yisroel, printed in Copenhagen 1917. Fairly straight forward, but always interesting to see Sefarim from less typical European areas. While quickly flipping through it I noticed that at the end of bentching there's a note to say "Yiru es Hashem" silently. Not a big deal, just something that stood out, as it's not mentioned in today's standard bentchers.

entry.title: IDF Siddur, Machzor and Tanach
entry.content:
I recently read an autobiogrophy on Rabbi Shlomo Goren - the first head of the military Rabbinate of the IDF. The book is mostly taken from a long interview the author had with R Goren in which R Goren is very straight forward and explains the logic behind many of the decisions he made as head of the Rabbinate in the IDF as well as later on as Chief Rabbi of Tel-Aviv and then as Chief Rabbi of Israel. In addition, there are many minor but interesting anecdotes about life in Israel and the Rabbonim in Yerushalayim from pre 1948 through the six day war.

In addition to shabbos, kashrus and burials (three of the main focuses of the IDF Rabbinate) the Rabbinate also prints Siddurim, Machzorim, Haggadahs, Megillas ect for the IDF.

This is an IDF Siddur from 1963; note the abbreviated Shmona Esrei that's included for davening during an emergency. Also, on the title page it has 'Nussach Achid' which was a nusach Rabbi Goren implemented as a single nusach everyone in the Army would use. It is a combination of nusach Ashkenaz, Ari and S'fardi.

This is an IDF machzor printed for Rosh Hashanah 1949 - "The second year of the State of Israel". Rabbi Goren's name is still Goronchik - which is what it originally was until Ben-Gurion asked him to modernize it and remove the "chik".

This is a Meggilas Esther with some interesting (and funny!) material.

Also - a couple Haggadahs (from more recent years) and a Tanach:
entry.summary: I recently read an autobiogrophy on Rabbi Shlomo Goren - the first head of the military Rabbinate of the IDF. The book is mostly taken from a long interview the author had with R Goren in which R Goren is very straight forward and explains the logic behind many of the decisions he made as head of the Rabbinate in the IDF as well as later on as Chief Rabbi of Tel-Aviv and then as Chief Rabbi of Israel. In addition, there are many minor but interesting anecdotes about life in Israel and the Rabbonim in Yerushalayim from pre 1948 through the six day war. In addition to shabbos, kashrus and burials (three of the main focuses of the IDF Rabbinate) the Rabbinate also prints Siddurim, Machzorim, Haggadahs, Megillas ect for the IDF. This is an IDF Siddur from 1963; note the abbreviated Shmona Esrei that's included for davening during an emergency. Also, on the title page it has 'Nussach Achid' which was a nusach Rabbi Goren implemented as a single nusach everyone in the Army would use. It is a combination of nusach Ashkenaz, Ari and S'fardi.

entry.title: Jewish Welfare Board Publications
entry.content:
Some of the most popular paraphernalia from Jewish soldiers serving in WW I and WW II (and the Korean war?) are books that were printed by the JWB (Jewish Welfare Board) and distributed to Jewish military personnel.  Siddurim, Machzorim, Tanachs, Haggadahs, Megillas and many other books/pamphlets/Jewish guides were printed by the thousands and are fairly easy to pick up today. If you're lucky, you can find one with a name & rank or some note written on the inside cover.

Here are some of the basics:

This is interesting - they used Tefillah K'tzarah for Shemonah Esrei........

A couple of cute postcards - would be really cool to have one that actually has a hand written message.... Apparently these were given to the soldiers as they returned to America; they'd send them to their families letting them know they were back on American soil and were heading home. Interesting details about the different types of postcards here.

Haggadah.......

A few somewhat less common pamphlets....
entry.summary: Some of the most popular paraphernalia from Jewish soldiers serving in WW I and WW II (and the Korean war?) are books that were printed by the JWB (Jewish Welfare Board) and distributed to Jewish military personnel. Siddurim, Machzorim, Tanachs, Haggadahs, Megillas and many other books/pamphlets/Jewish guides were printed by the thousands and are fairly easy to pick up today. If you're lucky, you can find one with a name & rank or some note written on the inside cover.

entry.title: Jewish German Almanac 1935 & 36 - Almanach des Schocken Verlags

link.title: Jewish German Almanac 1935 & 36 - Almanach des Schocken Verlags

entry.content:
This wasn't an extremely interesting find, but still cool. It's a pair of Jewish almanacs in German from 1935 and 1936. There seems to be a range of essays on different aspects and topics of Judaism and Zionism. One page that was particularly interesting was the list of global Jewish occupancy in the 1936 pamphlet (last image below). The almanacs were published by Schocken Verlag - a publishing company founded and owned by Salman (Zalman) Schocken. Salman eventually moved to Palestine and purchased the Ha'aretz newspaper. His descendants still have a 60% stake in the paper. You can read more about him on wikipedia.

1935 almanac:

and 1936:
entry.summary: This wasn't an extremely interesting find, but still cool. It's a pair of Jewish almanacs in German from 1935 and 1936. There seems to be a range of essays on different aspects and topics of Judaism and Zionism. One page that was particularly interesting was the list of global Jewish occupancy in the 1936 pamphlet (last image below). The almanacs were published by Schocken Verlag - a publishing company founded and owned by Salman (Zalman) Schocken. Salman eventually moved to Palestine and purchased the Ha'aretz newspaper. His descendants still have a 60% stake in the paper. You can read more about him on wikipedia.

entry.title: Rabbi Moshe Sherer works to free jewish hostages of 1970 hijacking

link.title: Rabbi Moshe Sherer works to free jewish hostages of 1970 hijacking

entry.content:
These notes by Rabbi Moshe Sherer are from the commemorative album put out by Agudath Israel of America in 1999 - Rabbi Moshe Sherer, his life and his legacy. They detail Rabbi Sherer's efforts to get the last Jewish hostages of the 1970 TWA hijacking ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawson%27s_Field_hijackings) home in time for Rosh Hashana.

Although this is not a particularly old book, it is a commemorative album which seems somewhat hard to come by. In addition, I found the hour by hour narrative super fascinating.
entry.summary: These notes by Rabbi Moshe Sherer are from the commemorative album put out by Agudath Israel of America in 1999 - Rabbi Moshe Sherer, his life and his legacy. They detail Rabbi Sherer's efforts to get the last Jewish hostages of the 1970 TWA hijacking ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawson%27s_Field_hijackings) home in time for Rosh Hashana. Although this is not a particularly old book, it is a commemorative album which seems somewhat hard to come by. In addition, I found the hour by hour narrative super fascinating.

entry.title: Sefarim printed right after WW II

link.title: Sefarim printed right after WW II

entry.content:
I'd like to continue last post's focus on material from post WW II. The following four sefarim are not from the DP camps but rather from Shanghai and from Mir in NY right after the war. Hopefully I'll do some future posts on WW II subject matter, with some sefarim printed by the American army for their soldiers, some Yidish and Hebrew books about the concentration camps written right after the war, and some general sefarim printed in the DP camps.

Ramban

Number one is a soft cover Ramban that says printed by Mir. The seller insisted it was printed in Shanghai, although I can't find any reference to that in the sefer itself. Lesson learned - be more vigilant and only buy something you can verify, at least to some minimal extent.

Shita Mekubetzes

Next is a shita mekubetzes on Nedarim printed by Yeshivas Mir in NY in 1947. Rabbi Avroham Kalmonowitz writes a very nice introduction about the importance of torah and how when the yeshiva was in Shanghai during the war and had extremely little to live on, they spent whatever they could to print sefarim.  The same when they came to NY; printing sefarim was one of the first things they did - even before they had a building for the yeshiva.

Maayana Shel Torah

Below is "Torah Kval" (Mayana shel Torah) in Yiddish, (two volumes; Bereishis, Shemos & Vayikra in one and the last two in the second volume) printed by Agudath Yisroel in Shanghai 1945. A couple of notes. 1. It has a clear name - seems it belonged to a Yechiel Efraim Halevi Shainwack.  2. This printing was dedicated to the author of the sefer who was killed by the Nazis in the Warsaw ghetto in 1943. 3. In the back of the first volume there is a gift note from a friend who signs off "Your brother in pain" 1946. It's hard to make out the complete name of the gifter.

Gemarah

Last is a Gemara Bechoros printed in Shanghai in about 1942. What is interesting is that it has a hand written name - Avroham Arbuz with a date, 8 Cheshvon 5703 (October 19, 1942). It then has a stamp that this sefer was from the property of the Bachur Avroham Yitzchak Yisroel Ben Tzvi Arbuz, a talmid of Mir who was niftar on 13 Shevat 5706 (January 15, 1946) in Shanghai. Sad. Couldn't find much online about this Arbuz, other than his name on a list of Mir talmidim (page 4 - number 97) and that apparently there are a plenty more sefarim with his name out there, as many people online also mention having sefarim with his name.
entry.summary: I'd like to continue last post's focus on material from post WW II. The following four sefarim are not from the DP camps but rather from Shanghai and from Mir in NY right after the war. Hopefully I'll do some future posts on WW II subject matter, with some sefarim printed by the American army for their soldiers, some Yidish and Hebrew books about the concentration camps written right after the war, and some general sefarim printed in the DP camps. Ramban

entry.title: DP Camp newspaper - Netzach Yisroel
entry.content:
Below are some pages from a Yiddish magazine printed in the DP camps in 1948. It provides a very clear and unique insight to their day to day life - similar to picking up a newspaper today and flipping through it; you walk away with a straightforward snapshot of that day, not someone writing 50 years later trying to reconstruct a bygone era. Since it was a magazine though, the paper quality is terrible and it is really crumbling apart. When I bought this one there was an identical copy also available - don't know what I was thinking but I just took the nicer of the two and left the second one there. Live and learn.... The last page is an index of the articles in this issue. Overall it is very heartening to see the strength and courage that was displayed so soon after the war...

PS - There was no way this wasn't going to entirely fall apart if I kept it at home. I sent it to Amudai Aish in Brooklyn, hopefully they have some benefit from it.

Since it was a magazine though, the paper quality is terrible and it is really crumbling apart. When I bought this one there was an identical copy also available - don't know what I was thinking but I just took the nicer of the two and left the second one there. Live and learn.... The last page is an index of the articles in this issue. Overall it is very heartening to see the strength and courage that was displayed so soon after the war... PS - There was no way this wasn't going to entirely fall apart if I kept it at home. I sent it to Amudai Aish in Brooklyn, hopefully they have some benefit from it.
